[http://www.camra.org.uk/ www.camra.org.uk] TheCampaign for Real Ale(CAMRA) is an independent voluntaryconsumer organisationheadquartered inSt Albans, England, which promotesreal ale,real ciderand the traditional Britishpublic housepub. It is now the largest single-issue consumer group in the UK,Cite bookhttp://books.google.com/?idEngland My England: A Treasury of ... - Google Books books.google.co.uk 2009-07-17
978-1-86105-893-5 2005 and is a founding member of theEuropean Beer Consumers' UnionEuropean Beer Consumers Union(EBCU).
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:Camra bar towel.JPGthumbrightCAMRA logo on a bar towelFile:1975-CAMRA.JPGthumb1975, 913 September- First National CAMRA Beer Festival held at Covent Garden, London.The organisation was founded in 1971 inDunquin, Kerry, Irelandcite webKey Events in CAMRA's Historyhttp://www.camra.org.uk/camrahistory25 July 2013by Michael Hardman, Graham Lees, Jim Makin, and Bill Mellor, who were opposed to the growing mass production of beer and the homogenisation of the Britishbrewingindustry. Other early influential members included Christopher Hutt, author ofDeath of the English Pub, who succeeded Hardman as chairman, Frank Baillie, author ofThe Beer Drinker's Companion, and later the currentGood Beer Guideeditor,Roger Protz. The original name was the Campaign for the Revitalisation of Ale.Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/4810832/Still-bitter-after-all-these-years.html Still bitter after all these years The Telegraph 2009-07-17 Neill Richard London 9 November 2000
article.heading: Aims

list.listitem: Promote quality, choice and value for money.
Support the public house as a focus of community life.
Campaign for greater appreciation of traditional beers, ciders and perries as part of our national heritage and culture.
Seek improvements in all licensed premises and throughout the brewing industry.cite webAbout Us - CAMRAhttp://www.camra.org.uk/about26 October 2011

article.paragraph: CAMRA's campaigns include promoting small brewing and pub businesses, reforming licensing laws, reducing tax on beer, and stopping continued consolidation among local British brewers.cite webCampaigns - CAMRAhttp://www.camra.org.uk/campaigns26 October 2011It also makes an effort to promote less common varieties of beer, includingStout beerstout,Porter (beer)porter, andMild beermild,cite webDifferent Styleshttp://www.camra.org.uk/beerstyles25 July 2013as well as traditionalciderandperry.cite webAbout Cider - CAMRAhttp://www.camra.org.uk/aboutcider26 October 2011

CAMRA does not support the promotion and sale of keg basedcraft beerin the UK. CAMRA's Internal Policy document states that real ale can only be served from cask without the use of additional carbonation. This policy means that "any beer brand which is produced in both cask and keg versions" is not admitted to CAMRA festivals or supported by CAMRA.cite webCromarty, CAMRA and crazy cask cancellationhttp://refreshingbeer.blogspot.co.uk/2013/03/cromarty-and-camra-we-are-not-all-idiots.html
article.heading: Organisation
article.paragraph: File:CamraBuildingHatfieldRoadStAlbans.jpgthumbThe CAMRA office building in St AlbansIn 2009, CAMRA announced that it had reached the 100,000 members mark and subsequently went on to pass the 150,000 members mark in 2013.citationhttp://www.camra.org.uk/page.php?idWhat is CAMRA? 4 April 2012 2012-04-04 CAMRAMember benefits include a monthly newspaper,What's Brewingand a quarterlyBEERmagazine, and free or reduced price admission to CAMRA-organisedbeer festivals. In recent times CAMRA has obtained benefits for its members from some commercial organisations and increasingly some licensed premises offer members price reductions on real ale (and sometimes cider and perry).

CAMRA is organised on a federal basis, with numerous independent local branches, each covering a particular geographical area of the UK, that contribute to the central body of the organisation based inSt Albans. It is governed by a voluntary unpaid national executive, elected by the membership.cite webWhat is CAMRA?http://wayback.archive.org/web/20110110102015/http://www.camra.org.uk/page.aspx?oCAMRA27 October 2011The local branches are grouped into 16 regions across the UK, such as theWest Midlands (region)West MidlandsorWessex.cite webCAMRA Near Youhttp://www.camra.org.uk/branchesCAMRA26 October 2011

The current National Chairman is Colin Valentine, who took over from Paula Waters in February 2010. The long term Chief Executive was Mike Benner until June 2014 and his vacancy has been filled with effect from November 2014 by Tim Page.cite press releaseCAMRA appoints new National ChairmanCAMRA15 February 2010http://www.camra.org.uk/article.php?group_id22 July 2013

CAMRA has established influence at national government level, includingEnglish Heritage, and has been designated by theSecretary of State for Trade and Industryas a "super-complainant" to theOffice of Fair Trading.citationhttp://www.opsi.gov.uk/SI/si2005/20052340.htm The Enterprise Act 2002 (Bodies Designated to make Super-complaints) Order 2005 2005 [[The Stationery Office]] 2009-05-05
article.heading: Events and publications
article.paragraph: CAMRA publishes theGood Beer Guide, an annually compiled directory of its recommended pubs and brewers; theGood Cider Guide, an occasionally compiled directory of pubs that sell realCider; theGood Bottled Beer Guide, an occasionally compiled review ofreal alein a bottle.CAMRA members receive a monthly newspaper calledWhat's Brewingand a quarterly colour magazine calledBeer.It also runs theGreat British Beer Festival, a yearly event held in London at which a large selection ofcask alesand ciders are tasted. It also maintains aCAMRA Pub Heritage GroupNational Inventory of Historic Pub Interiorsto help bring greater recognition and protection to Britain's most historic pubs. In 2013 CAMRA launched public access to a national pub database website called Whatpub.com which is maintained by CAMRA members through the branches structure.
article.heading: Festivals
article.paragraph: File:GBBF 2.jpgthumbGreat British Beer Festival 2004CAMRA supports and promotes numerous beer and cider festivals around the country each year, which are organised by local CAMRA branches around the UK. Generally, each festival charges an entry fee which varies depending upon the area, and either covers entry only or includes a commemorative , or 1pint glasssporting the details of the festival. A festival programme is usually also provided, listing the drinks available for tasting and providing a brief description of each beverage.List of upcoming CAMRA beer festivals
The Campaign also organises the annual Great British Beer Festival in August, held in the Great Hall Kensington Olympia, London, having been a few years at Earl's Court .Great British Beer Festival
article.heading: Awards
article.paragraph: CAMRA presents awards for beers and pubs, such as theNational Pub of the Year, in which approximately 4,000 active CAMRA members from 200 local branches vote for their favourite pub of the year. The branch winners are entered into 16 regional competitions which are then visited by several individuals who select the ones they like best. There are also thePub Design Awards, which are held in association withEnglish HeritageandThe Victorian Society. These comprise several categories, including new build, refurbished and converted pubs. The best known CAMRA award is theChampion Beer of Britain,citationhttp://www.camra.org.uk/cbob Campaign for Real Ale Champion Beer of Britain 25 July 2013 which is selected at theGreat British Beer Festival, other awards include theChampion Beer of Scotlandand theChampion Beer of Wales.
article.heading: National Beer Scoring Scheme
article.paragraph: CAMRA developed the "National Beer Scoring Scheme"citationhttp://www.camra.org.uk/nbss National Beer Scoring Scheme Campaign for Real Ale 12 January 2006 BrettLaniosh 25 July 2013 (NBSS) as an easy to use scheme for judging beer quality in pubs, to assist CAMRA branches in selecting pubs for theGood Beer Guide. The person filling in the form records their name, date, the pub, the beer and the score.The scores range from 0, meaning that no real ale is available; increasing in increments of 0.5 through 2, which signifies an average beer that is drunk without calling attention to itself in either a positive or negative manner; up to 5, which signifies a perfect beer. CAMRA members may also input their beer scores on line via the CAMRA website Whatpub.com.
article.heading: Pub heritage group
article.paragraph: The "CAMRA Pub Heritage Group" is a group established to identify, record and help protectpubinteriors of historic and/or architectural importance, and seeks to get themListed buildinglisted, if not already.citationhttp://www.heritagepubs.org.uk Heritage Pubs - An Overview Campaign for Real Ale 2009-05-05

The group maintains two inventories of "Heritage pubs", the National Inventory (NI), which contains only those pubs that have been maintained in their original condition (or have been modified very little) for at least 30 years, but usually since at leastWorld War II. The second, larger inventory is the Regional Inventory (RI), which is broken down byCounties of the United Kingdomcountyand contains both those pubs listed in the NI and other pubs that are not eligible for the NI, for reasons such as having been overly modified, but are still considered historically important, or have particular architectural value.

The NI contains 289 pubsas of20096on.cite webhttp://wayback.archive.org/web/20090629082124/http://www.heritagepubs.org.uk/home/nationalinventory.asp Pub Heritage, the Campaign for Real Ale www.heritagepubs.org.uk 2009-07-17
article.heading: LocAle
article.paragraph: With the main aims in mind, the group launched theLocAlescheme in 2007 which was developed by Steve Westby'Check your beers urges LocAle creator', What's Brewing, August 2010 issueof theNottinghambranchCAMRA LocAle(accessed 25 July 2013)to help promote locally brewed beers and also help with environmental issues. The scheme functions slightly differently in each area, and is managed by each branch, but the overall rule is that each participating pub is allowed to purchase beer from whatever brewery they wish, but if the beer is to be promoted as a 'LocAle' it must come from a brewery within a predetermined number of miles (which is set by each CAMRA branch, but generally is around 20 or 25 miles,LocAle - More Information & Downloads for Licensees(accessed 25 July 2013)although the NorthLondonbranch has set it at 30 milesCAMRA North London - LocAle(accessed 6 September 2010)) from brewery to pub door,'LocAle boosts local tourism',What's Brewing, September 2010 issueeven if it comes from a distribution centre further away;in addition, each participating pub must keep at least one LocAle for sale at all times.
